page.title: 08Portslade Old Village
page.content: Horses grazing opposite the church, squirrels in Easthill Park gathering conkers,many old flint walls,children playing cricket on The Green,views of open downland behind the tall chimney of the old brewery, contribute to the peaceful village atmosphere on a Sunday.One can imagine farm carts trundling up the High Street past the Stag's Head,village pond and labourers cottages a hundred years ago.Come on a week day and this same road is choked with traffic from the nearby estate. The two hundred year old cottages, Robin's Row,the cottage with the crooked tower to ward off the devil, the old forge and the church with two skeleton heads engraved in the floor, the Manor House,now a convent and Whytecroft,a seventeenth century gabled house tell us that Portslade once housed the gentry.
